intro: Corispermum apetalum, commonly known as the naked bladderwort, is a small flowering plant belonging to the family Brassicaceae. It is characterized by its simple, erect stems and small, inconspicuous flowers that lack petals, giving it its scientific name. The plant produces small, spherical fruits called siliques, which contain seeds enclosed in a membranous sac. It typically grows in moist, sandy soils and is often found in coastal areas or along riverbanks. Corispermum apetalum is an annual plant that plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local insect populations.
